caption: Supporters of Tanzania's ruling Chama Cha Mapinduzi party come out on Friday to celebrate their candidate's victory in the disputed Zanzibari presidential election

result.explanation: The image shows a person sitting on top of a vehicle, possibly in a celebratory context.  However, there is no clear visual evidence to confirm the affiliation with Chama Cha Mapinduzi party or the specific location as Zanzibar. The clothing and setting suggest a location in Africa, which aligns with Tanzania, and the celebration could be related to an election, but more visual information is needed for certainty. The caption mentions a "disputed Zanzibari presidential election," and the image only shows the celebration, without showing anything about the dispute.

candidates.title: Tanzania poll: John Magufuli of CCM defeats Edward Lowassa
candidates.content:
Tanzania's governing CCM party candidate John Magufuli has won the presidential election with 58% of the vote, the electoral commission says.
His main rival Edward Lowassa has rejected the official results that gave him 40% of the ballots cast.
The opposition Ukawa coalition candidate earlier claimed he had won with 62% of the vote.
The elections on Sunday were the most fierce the governing party faced after 54 years in power.
Africa Live: BBC news updates
John Magufuli is celebrating his 56th birthday so the presidency is a perfect gift for him. He was never a CCM insider and confounded many when he was elected as the ruling party's presidential candidate.
As works minister in the outgoing government, Mr Magufuli was reputed to be a no-nonsense, results-driven politician. He became known as "The Bulldozer" for driving a programme to build roads across the country.
He campaigned for the presidency on a platform of hard work, and will now have to tackle far bigger problems facing the East African state. This includes constant power outages, and corruption - an issue which led to many people turning against CCM in the election.
'The Bulldozer' in profile
President Jakaya Kikwete, who is standing down after two terms in office, retweeted a CCM photo of Mr Magufuli, external and the accompanying words: "Our next Commander-in-Chief, Dr John Pombe Magufuli, the President-elect of The United Republic of Tanzania."
Abdallah Safari, vice-president of Chadema, one of the four opposition parties that make up Ukama, told the BBC that Tanzanians "have been robbed of their victory".
BBC Tanzania analyst Zuhura Yunus says the result is a big blow for Mr Lowassa after four opposition parties put their faith in him, uniting for the first time to field a single candidate.
candidates.description: Tanzania's governing party candidate John Magufuli has won Sunday's fiercely competitive presidential election with 58% of the vote, officials say.

result.explanation: Source 1 discusses the presidential election victory of John Magufuli of the CCM party, but it does not mention any celebrations by supporters on Friday following a disputed Zanzibari election.  The caption and the source refer to different elections (presidential vs. Zanzibari). The source also lacks information about the Zanzibari election being disputed.
result.supporting_points: Source 1 focuses on the Tanzanian presidential election, not a Zanzibari election. There is no mention of a Friday celebration or any dispute in the Zanzibari election.

final_result.explanation:
The original caption states that the image depicts supporters of Tanzania's ruling Chama Cha Mapinduzi (CCM) party celebrating their candidate's victory in a disputed Zanzibari presidential election on a Friday.  Both the internal and external validation checks cast significant doubt on this caption's accuracy.

Internal Check:
The internal check highlights a lack of visual evidence to confirm the affiliation with the CCM party or the specific location as Zanzibar. While the clothing and setting suggest an African location, consistent with Tanzania, the image only shows a celebration; there's no visual information about any election dispute. The confidence score of 6 reflects this uncertainty.

External Check:
The external check reinforces the doubts.  The referenced source focuses on the Tanzanian presidential election victory of John Magufuli, not a Zanzibari election.  Crucially, it contains no information about a disputed Zanzibari election or a Friday celebration following such an event. The low confidence score of 3 reflects the absence of supporting evidence.

Discrepancies and Conflicts:
Both the internal and external checks independently conclude that the caption is likely inaccurate. There is no corroborating evidence from either the image or the external source to support the claim made in the caption.  The caption mentions a specific event (a disputed Zanzibari presidential election and subsequent celebration) lacking visual and external verification.

Entity Analysis:
Entity analysis shows a mismatch. The caption mentions a specific political party (CCM), a specific geographic location (Zanzibar), a specific event (a disputed election), and a specific day (Friday). The image only shows a person in festive attire sitting on a vehicle, which is not enough to confirm any of the specific details stated in the caption.  There is no visible CCM party paraphernalia or any indication it is in Zanzibar. 

Conclusion:
Given the low confidence scores from both the internal (6) and external (3) checks, and the absence of supporting evidence from the image itself or the external source, it's highly likely that the original caption is out of context. The lack of verifiable details within the image and the external source's focus on a different election decisively point to the caption being inaccurate. Therefore, the final confidence score is a conservative 4, reflecting the substantial uncertainty surrounding the caption's accuracy. The significant inconsistencies between the caption's claims and the available evidence lead to the conclusion that the caption is out of context.
final_result.validation_summary: Both internal and external validation checks show low confidence in the accuracy of the original caption.  The image lacks visual evidence to support the claims about the political party, location, and the specific disputed Zanzibari election.  The external source focuses on a different election entirely, failing to corroborate any of the events mentioned in the caption.
